awd_titl_txt: Synthesis and investigation of acylhydrazone hemicarcerands and nanocapsules
awd_abstract_narration:
With the support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry, Prof. Ralf Warmuth of Rutgers University New Brunswick conducts research to construct "dynamic nanocapsules" in water for entrapping proteins and studying the effects of encapsulation on protein activity.  Specifically, the Warmuth group is developing methodologies for the one-pot multi-component synthesis of different nanometer-sized molecular capsules using reversible acylhydrazone chemistry.   Kinetic and mechanistic investigations will be performed to gain insights into the dynamic features and stability of these capsules.  The role of solvents for the formation of these capsules will be examined.  In addition, this research group will explore methodologies for the encapsulation of insulin inside a water-soluble rhombicuboctahedral nanocapsule.  

The development of thermodynamically controlled synthesis of nanocapsules and the studies of these capsules will advance knowledge in supramolecular chemistry and have impacts on nanoscience and nanotechnology.  The investigation of the potential of these nanocapsules to entrap and influence the properties of the encapsulated proteins (especially insulin) would provide insights into methods for controlling protein activities and would broadly impact biological and medical fields.  Furthermore, this project will provide multidisciplinary research training for graduate, undergraduate, and high school students.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Research has been conducted that led to the development of a rational design strategy for the multi-component assembly of nanometer-sized dynamic molecular capsules and the characterization of some of their molecular recognition properties. These capsules are built-up from rigid cup-shaped cavitand molecules with four reactive groups at their rim and linked rim-to-rim by linear ditopic or trigonal planar tritopic connectors through multiple dynamic bonds. The latter can reversibly break and reform, which provides an error-correction and proof-reading mechanism during capsule assembly leading to extremely high efficiency in the assembly. The results of our research provide a road map for choosing the correct geometry of the building blocks, such that the assembly process leads to spherical capsules with cavitand-to-connector ratio of 2:4, 4:8, 6:12, or 6:8, whose cavity approaches the size of smaller biomacromolecules (Chart 1). As part this project, we have provided insight into the driving forces for capsule assembly and the relationship between capsule stability and geometry and flexibility of the linker components as well as the nature of the solvent. Our findings serve as guidelines for design and assembly of water-soluble capsules, which may find applications in the medical field as vehicles for drug, protein or RNA delivery or for the capture and removal of toxins from waste water and through this will benefit society.

A specific aim of the project has been the development of such water-soluble capsules. Towards this goal, we have developed different ways of attaching highly polar groups to the cavitand building blocks and/or the connectors and have investigated whether such capsules can assemble in water. Ultimately, our research provided multiple water-soluble [6+12]- and [6+8]-assemblies with cavity sizes of several nanometers. We also uncovered a [6+8]-assembly that is dynamic and partially dissociates into its constituents in water under physiological conditions, which we think is a promising property for application in protein and RNA encapsulation and delivery.

We have developed several [2+4] container molecules, that assemble spontaneously in water in the presence of suitable hydrocarbon guests. We have shown that these capsules (a) can serve as ?molecular reaction flasks? and allow photochemical transformations of an encapsulated guest, (b) can protect the encapsulated guest from decomposition and (c) show high size and shape selectivity in their encapsulation of small hydrocarbon guests, allowing selective capture of one among different isomers, which are properties that make them interesting for application in industrial separation of hydrocarbons, fragrance delivery or waste water purification. 

We have explored the synthesis of dynamic [2+4] capsules and their molecular recognition in the solid-state. Our research shows, that these capsules assemble through neat or liquid-assisted ball-mill grinding and allow guest encapsulation, if grinded in the presence of guest molecules. Benefits of this solid-state approach over solution phase encapsulation are the mild conditions and absence of solvent competition. This approach also paves the way for large scale, environmentally friendly and cost-efficient syntheses of molecular capsules, which will facilitate their entry into industrial applications.

The project has contributed to the training of the next generation of STEM workforce. During the project period, 16 research associates, graduate students and undergraduate students (7 female and 9 male), of which two belong to underrepresented groups in the STEM fields, participated at the research activities. They received valuable training in the characterization, preparation and purification of small, medium and macromolecular compounds, the interpretation and communication of research results and the design of experiments that prove or disprove research hypotheses, all of which provided them with an excellent foundation for future careers in education, chemical and pharmaceutical research & development or the medical field. In addition, four high school students (three from underrepresented groups in STEM) have spent between 4-8 weeks during the summer in the Warmuth laboratory and have gained insight into the daily life of a research scientist and inspiration to pursue college degrees.


Last Modified: 09/18/2022
Modified by: Ralf Warmuth

Image
  • 6+12]-, [6+8]- and [2+4]-capsules and building blocks
    Ralf Warmuth
    Copyrighted
    Ralf Warmuth
    Dynamic Covalent Nanocapsules
